title: Ezekiel Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 21.

questions.question: To whom did the word of the LORD come according to Ezekiel 21:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:1 states that the word of the LORD came unto Ezekiel.

questions.question: What was Ezekiel instructed to set his face toward in Ezekiel 21:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:2 says, 'Son of man, set thy face toward Jerusalem.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 21:3, what will the LORD draw forth out of his sheath?
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:3 states that the LORD will draw forth his sword out of his sheath.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 21:4 states that the sword will only cut off the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:4 says the sword will cut off both the righteous and the wicked.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the sword going forth from the south to the north in Ezekiel 21:4?
questions.correctAnswer: To cut off all flesh
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:4 explains the sword will go forth against all flesh from south to north.

questions.question: What will happen to every spirit and knee when the tidings come, according to Ezekiel 21:7?
options: Every spirit shall faint and knees be weak as water
questions.correctAnswer: Every spirit shall faint and knees be weak as water
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:7 describes hearts melting, spirits fainting, and knees being weak as water.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21:9, what is said about the sword?
questions.correctAnswer: It is sharpened and furbished
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:9 says 'A sword, a sword is sharpened, and also furbished.'

questions.question: What action is Ezekiel told to do in Ezekiel 21:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Cry and howl
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:12 commands Ezekiel to cry and howl for the terrors by reason of the sword.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 21:15, where has the point of the sword been set?
questions.correctAnswer: Against all their gates
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:15 states that the point of the sword is set against all their gates.

questions.question: What decision is Ezekiel asked to make in Ezekiel 21:16?
options: Go to the left or right
questions.correctAnswer: Go to the left or right
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:16 instructs to go one way or other, either right hand or left.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 21:21, the king of Babylon used divination including arrows and looking in the liver.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:21 describes the king of Babylon using arrows, images, and looking in the liver for divination.

questions.question: What does the king of Babylon appoint for Jerusalem according to Ezekiel 21:22?
questions.correctAnswer: Captains and battering rams
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:22 lists captains, battering rams, forts, and mounts appointed against Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who is called the 'profane wicked prince of Israel' in Ezekiel 21:25?
questions.correctAnswer: The prince of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:25 refers to 'thou, profane wicked prince of Israel'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 21:26: 'Remove the _______, and take off the crown.'
questions.correctAnswer: diadem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:26 commands to remove the diadem and take off the crown.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 21:32, the LORD said that the blood of the wicked shall be remembered forever.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:32 states the wicked shall be no more remembered because the LORD has spoken it.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear amid trials. Based on Ezekiel 21, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's judgment?
options: God's sword is drawn and will not return until His purpose is fulfilled
God will abandon His people in times of trouble
Human strength alone can overcome all adversity
Trials are meaningless and without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God's sword is drawn and will not return until His purpose is fulfilled
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:5 states that God's sword has been drawn out of its sheath and will not return, showing that God's judgment is certain and purposeful. Verses 3, 4, and 7 emphasize that God's actions are deliberate and should lead believers to trust His sovereign plan.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21 teach us about humility when facing God's discipline?
options: Exalt the low and abase the high as God's will dictates
Ignore God's discipline and continue as before
Seek to justify your sins before God
Rely on your own righteousness to avoid consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Exalt the low and abase the high as God's will dictates
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:26 instructs to remove the diadem and crown, exalting the low and abasing the high, teaching humility and submission to God's sovereign will. Verses 25 and 27 highlight the end of iniquity and God's overturning of earthly powers.

questions.question: A believer is confused about how to respond to impending judgment. According to Ezekiel 21, what attitude should they adopt?
options: Sigh with bitterness and show sorrow openly
Celebrate and make mirth despite the warning
Ignore the prophecy and live carelessly
questions.correctAnswer: Sigh with bitterness and show sorrow openly
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:6 commands the son of man to sigh with bitterness and show sorrow before the people, indicating the need for a humble and repentant attitude. Verses 7 and 12 also emphasize mourning and lamentation as appropriate responses to God's warnings.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21 emphasize the importance of obedience and faithfulness in leadership?
options: God will remove the crown from the wicked prince and overturn his rule
Leaders will always remain in power regardless of their actions
Leadership is based on human strength and wisdom alone
questions.correctAnswer: God will remove the crown from the wicked prince and overturn his rule
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:25-27 speaks of the removal of the crown from the wicked prince and God's overturning of his rule, showing that leadership must be faithful to God or face consequences. This teaches accountability and the need for humility and obedience in leadership roles.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 21 teach us about perseverance through trials?
options: God's sword is sharpened and furbished for judgment, so perseverance includes trusting His sovereign plan
Trials are random and without meaning
We should avoid trials at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: God's sword is sharpened and furbished for judgment, so perseverance includes trusting His sovereign plan
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 describe God's sword as sharpened and furbished for slaughter, indicating the certainty of judgment. Believers are called to persevere by trusting God's sovereign purpose through trials (verses 4, 5, 7).

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage believers to maintain integrity in daily life despite challenges?
options: Recognize that both the righteous and the wicked are subject to God's judgment, so live with honesty and faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that both the righteous and the wicked are subject to God's judgment, so live with honesty and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:3-4 states that God's sword will cut off both the righteous and the wicked, reminding believers to live with integrity and faithfulness, not relying on personal merit but on obedience to God.

questions.question: A believer asks about God's justice. According to Ezekiel 21, what should they understand about divine judgment?
options: God's judgment is thorough and impartial, affecting all from south to north
God shows favoritism to the righteous only
God's sword will return to its sheath without effect
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is thorough and impartial, affecting all from south to north
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 explain that God's sword goes forth against all flesh from south to north and will not return, highlighting the impartial and comprehensive nature of divine judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 21 teaches that God's plans can be changed by human divination or false signs.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:21-23 shows that the king of Babylon used divination, but it was false in the sight of God, who remembered iniquity and executed His plans. This confirms God's plans are sovereign and not altered by false signs.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 21, God's wrath is poured out on those who persist in iniquity and rebellion.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 30-32 describe God pouring out indignation and wrath on those who persist in sin, delivering them into the hands of destroyers and making them fuel for fire, showing the certainty of divine judgment on persistent rebellion.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 21, the sword is described as being __________ and furbished to give it into the hand of the slayer.
questions.correctAnswer: sharpened
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:11 states the sword is sharpened and furbished to be handled by the slayer, emphasizing the readiness of God's judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21 teach about the importance of repentance in the face of God's discipline?
options: God calls for mourning and lamentation as signs of repentance
Repentance is unnecessary because judgment is fixed
Trust only in human strength to escape judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God calls for mourning and lamentation as signs of repentance
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 7, and 12 instruct the son of man to sigh, cry, and howl before the people, symbolizing the call to repentance and mourning in response to God's discipline.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from the prophecy against the Ammonites in Ezekiel 21?
options: Pride leads to downfall and God's wrath
God favors the proud and powerful
Contentment is irrelevant to God's judgment
Ammonites will be spared due to their strength
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and God's wrath
questions.explanation: Verses 28-32 describe the sword drawn against the Ammonites due to their iniquity and pride, serving as a warning about the consequences of arrogance and the value of humility.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21 illustrate the importance of trusting God's timing and sovereignty?
options: God will overturn worldly powers until the rightful one comes
God's plans are immediate and unchangeable by prayer
Human efforts control the outcome of events
Timing is irrelevant to God's plans
questions.correctAnswer: God will overturn worldly powers until the rightful one comes
questions.explanation: Verse 27 declares God will overturn the crown until the one whose right it is appears, teaching believers to trust His timing and sovereignty over human affairs.

questions.question: A fellow believer is tempted to despair because of looming judgment. Based on Ezekiel 21, what encouragement would you offer about God's purpose in trials?
options: God's judgment is a trial meant to reveal iniquity and lead to accountability
Despair is the only response to judgment
God's judgment can be avoided by ignoring it
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is a trial meant to reveal iniquity and lead to accountability
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:13-14 explains the sword is a trial and will expose iniquity, showing that God's discipline serves to bring accountability and correction.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 21 teach about the role of prophecy and preaching in the church life?
options: Prophets must boldly declare God's word, including warnings and calls to repentance
Preaching is optional and not necessary
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets must boldly declare God's word, including warnings and calls to repentance
questions.explanation: Throughout Ezekiel 21 (verses 2, 9, 14, 28), the son of man is commanded to prophesy and pronounce God's judgment, teaching the necessity of faithful, bold proclamation in church life.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 21.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21:3, what does the LORD say He will draw out of its sheath against the land of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:3 explicitly states that the LORD will draw forth His sword out of its sheath against Israel, symbolizing divine judgment.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ezekiel 21:14 with the phrase 'let the sword be doubled the third time'?
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition
questions.explanation: The phrase 'let the sword be doubled the third time' shows repetition to emphasize the severity and certainty of judgment (Ezekiel 21:14).

questions.question: Ezekiel 21:21 describes the king of Babylon using divination at the parting of the way. Which ancient Near Eastern practice is referenced here?
questions.correctAnswer: Hepatoscopy (liver divination)
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:21 mentions the king looking in the liver, a form of hepatoscopy, an ancient divination practice common in the Near East.

questions.question: Which theme in Ezekiel 21 is foreshadowed by the sword imagery and later echoed in the New Testament as a symbol of divine judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: The coming Messianic judgment
questions.explanation: The sword as a symbol of judgment in Ezekiel 21 anticipates the New Testament theme of divine judgment, such as in Revelation's use of the sword imagery.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 21:25-26, what is commanded to be removed from the 'profane wicked prince of Israel'?
questions.correctAnswer: The diadem and the crown
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:26 commands removal of the diadem and crown, signifying the end of the prince's authority and the reversal of fortunes.

questions.question: Ezekiel 21:22 describes Babylon's preparations for siege against Jerusalem. Which of the following was NOT mentioned as part of this preparation?
questions.correctAnswer: Digging a tunnel
questions.explanation: The verse lists appointing captains, building a fort, and casting a mount, but does not mention digging a tunnel (Ezekiel 21:22).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21:7, what physical responses are prophesied for the people when the tidings come?
options: Hearts melting, hands becoming feeble, spirits fainting, knees weak as water
questions.correctAnswer: Hearts melting, hands becoming feeble, spirits fainting, knees weak as water
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:7 describes the people's fearful reaction with hearts melting and knees becoming weak, symbolizing overwhelming dread.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 21:9-11 portrays the sword as contemptuous of the rod of the LORD’s son, symbolizing rebellion against divine authority.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:10 states the sword contemns the rod of the LORD's son, indicating defiance against divine discipline.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'it shall be no more, until he come whose right it is' found in Ezekiel 21:27?
options: It indicates a future rightful ruler will receive the kingdom
It refers to the permanent destruction of Israel
It means the sword will never return to its sheath
It signifies the end of all prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a future rightful ruler will receive the kingdom
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:27 foreshadows a Messianic figure who will ultimately receive rightful authority, a theme consistent with biblical typology.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21:20, which two locations are identified as targets of the king of Babylon's sword?
options: Rabbath of the Ammonites and Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Rabbath of the Ammonites and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:20 explicitly mentions Rabbath of the Ammonites and Jerusalem as destinations for Babylon’s invading sword.

questions.question: What role does the motif of 'smiting on the thigh' play in Ezekiel 21:12 within the prophetic context?
options: A gesture of mourning and lamentation
questions.correctAnswer: A gesture of mourning and lamentation
questions.explanation: In Ezekiel 21:12, smiting the thigh is a cultural expression of intense sorrow and anguish, underscoring the coming terror.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 21:31, God says He will deliver the Ammonites into the hand of ________ men, skilled to destroy.
questions.correctAnswer: brutish
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:31 states that Ammon will be delivered into the hand of brutish men skilled to destroy, expressing divine wrath.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21:16 reflect the uncertainty of the Babylonian king’s path of conquest?
options: By stating 'Go thee one way or other, either on the right hand, or on the left'
By naming the precise cities to be attacked
By commanding the king to retreat
questions.correctAnswer: By stating 'Go thee one way or other, either on the right hand, or on the left'
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:16 shows the ambiguity in the direction of the sword, symbolizing the unpredictability of Babylon's attack route.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word conceptually underlies the 'sword' imagery in Ezekiel 21 and is often associated with divine execution of justice?
questions.correctAnswer: Chereb
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'chereb' means sword and is used throughout Ezekiel 21 to symbolize God's judgment and justice.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 21:24, why will the people be taken 'with the hand'?
options: Because their iniquities are remembered and their sins appear
Because they refused to build the temple
Because they worshiped other gods secretly
Because they fled from the land
questions.correctAnswer: Because their iniquities are remembered and their sins appear
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:24 explains that the people's remembrance for their iniquity and visible transgressions leads to their capture.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary divine action described in Ezekiel 21 concerning Israel?
options: God will draw forth His sword and cut off both the righteous and the wicked
God will bless Israel abundantly and restore the temple
God will send a prophet to guide Israel into righteousness
God will establish peace and prosperity in the land
questions.correctAnswer: God will draw forth His sword and cut off both the righteous and the wicked
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:3-4 states that God is against Israel and will draw forth His sword to cut off both the righteous and the wicked, highlighting the comprehensive judgment decreed by God. This is consistent with divine judgment themes in Scripture such as Isaiah 13:11, Romans 11:22, and Hebrews 10:31, where God's judgment is both righteous and all-encompassing.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21, what is the purpose of the sword going forth from God's sheath?
options: That all flesh may know the LORD has drawn His sword and it shall not return
To conquer foreign nations and establish Israel's dominion
To provide protection for the righteous against the wicked
To symbolize peace and reconciliation among the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: That all flesh may know the LORD has drawn His sword and it shall not return
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:5 explains that the sword is drawn so all flesh may know the LORD’s judgment is certain and irreversible. This reflects God's attribute of justice and sovereignty, similar to the irrevocable judgments in Psalm 75:7 and Isaiah 54:17, emphasizing the certainty of God's acts.

questions.question: How does the prophet Ezekiel express his sorrow and bitterness before the people according to Ezekiel 21?
options: By sighing with the breaking of his loins and bitterness before their eyes
By fasting for forty days and nights
By weeping silently in his chamber
questions.correctAnswer: By sighing with the breaking of his loins and bitterness before their eyes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:6 commands Ezekiel to sigh bitterly with the breaking of his loins before the people, a vivid expression of grief and impending judgment, paralleling other prophetic expressions of sorrow such as Jeremiah 4:19 and Isaiah 37:3.

questions.question: What imagery is used to describe the sword in Ezekiel 21:9-11?
options: A sharpened and furbished sword, made to slaughter and glitter
A dull and broken sword, symbolizing weakness
A flaming sword guarding the garden
A ceremonial sword used only in worship
questions.correctAnswer: A sharpened and furbished sword, made to slaughter and glitter
questions.explanation: Verses 21:9-11 describe the sword as sharpened and furbished to make a sore slaughter and to glitter, symbolizing God's readiness and decisiveness in judgment. This parallels imagery in Revelation 1:16 and Hebrews 4:12, where the sword represents the word and judgment of God.

questions.question: Who is the sword intended to strike according to Ezekiel 21:12?
options: The people of Israel and their princes
questions.correctAnswer: The people of Israel and their princes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:12 declares the sword will fall upon God's people and all princes of Israel, indicating judgment upon both commoners and leaders alike. This reflects God's impartial judgment as seen in passages like Jeremiah 25:15 and Romans 2:11.

questions.question: What does God instruct Ezekiel to do three times concerning the sword in Ezekiel 21:14?
options: Smite his hands together and let the sword be doubled the third time
Bear the sword and fight against the enemies
Hide the sword to protect the righteous
Pray for mercy to stop the sword
questions.correctAnswer: Smite his hands together and let the sword be doubled the third time
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:14 commands the prophet to smite his hands and let the sword be doubled the third time, symbolizing intensified judgment and the certainty of death for the great men slain. This echoes the symbolic acts of prophets such as Jeremiah (Jeremiah 13:18) conveying divine judgment.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 21:19-23, what method does the king of Babylon use to decide the direction of his attack?
options: Divination using arrows, images, and looking at the liver
Praying to his gods for guidance
Using military strategy without supernatural means
questions.correctAnswer: Divination using arrows, images, and looking at the liver
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:21 describes the king of Babylon using divination practices—making arrows bright, consulting images, and examining the liver—to decide his course. This highlights the contrast between pagan divination and God's sovereign control over events, as also seen in Daniel 2:27-28 and Isaiah 47:13.

questions.question: What is God's verdict on the iniquity of Israel's leaders as expressed in Ezekiel 21:25-26?
options: Remove the diadem and take off the crown; exalt the low and abase the high
Restore the kingship and strengthen their rule
Ignore the sins and continue as before
questions.correctAnswer: Remove the diadem and take off the crown; exalt the low and abase the high
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:25-26 pronounces the removal of the crown and diadem from the 'profane wicked prince,' denoting the end of his reign and a reversal of fortunes. This reflects God's just judgment in leadership as seen in Isaiah 14:4-6 and Daniel 4:17.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'I will overturn, overturn, overturn it' in Ezekiel 21:27 signify about God's plan?
options: Complete and final removal of the current rule until the rightful one comes
Temporary suspension of judgment for repentance
Establishment of perpetual monarchy in Israel
A call to rebuild the temple quickly
questions.correctAnswer: Complete and final removal of the current rule until the rightful one comes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:27 communicates God's decisive overthrow of the current regime until 'he come whose right it is,' a messianic anticipation consistent with Psalm 2:7-9 and Daniel 7:13-14, pointing to the ultimate rightful King.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 21:28-32, what is the fate of the Ammonites?
options: They will be consumed by the sword and become fuel for fire
They will be spared and blessed by God
They will form an alliance with Israel
They will be relocated to another land
questions.correctAnswer: They will be consumed by the sword and become fuel for fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:31-32 declares God's indignation poured out on the Ammonites, delivering them into the hands of destroyers so they become fuel for fire, indicating total destruction. This judgment aligns with God's justice on nations opposing His people as seen in Nahum 1:2-3 and Jeremiah 25:15.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 21 illustrate God's attribute of sovereignty over history and judgment?
options: By showing God directing the sword's path and controlling kings' decisions
By depicting God as passive during Israel’s fall
By allowing human free will to override divine plans
By focusing only on individual repentance
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God directing the sword's path and controlling kings' decisions
questions.explanation: Throughout Ezekiel 21, God demonstrates sovereignty by commanding judgment and even directing the king of Babylon’s decisions (Ezekiel 21:19-23). This is consistent with biblical theology of God's providence as in Proverbs 21:1 and Acts 17:26.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the sword cutting off both the righteous and the wicked in Ezekiel 21:3-4?
options: God’s righteous judgment can affect the entire community, indicating corporate responsibility
Only the wicked are punished while the righteous are exempt
God’s mercy always prevents judgment on the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God’s righteous judgment can affect the entire community, indicating corporate responsibility
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:3-4 shows that judgment will not discriminate between righteous and wicked, highlighting corporate accountability in Israel’s sin. This theme is supported by passages like Exodus 20:5 and Romans 5:12, emphasizing the communal consequences of sin.

questions.question: In what way does Ezekiel 21 relate to eschatological hope despite its message of judgment?
options: It foretells the coming of 'he whose right it is' who will receive the crown
It predicts permanent destruction with no restoration
It focuses only on historical Babylonian conquest
It emphasizes human effort over divine intervention
questions.correctAnswer: It foretells the coming of 'he whose right it is' who will receive the crown
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21:27 anticipates a future rightful ruler receiving the crown, a messianic hope that points to Christ’s kingship, consistent with Isaiah 9:6-7 and Revelation 19:16, offering hope beyond judgment.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the sword in Ezekiel 21 connect to Christological themes in the New Testament?
options: The sword represents the word of God, piercing to judge and bring salvation
The sword symbolizes only physical warfare without spiritual significance
The sword is a symbol of human violence unrelated to divine action
The sword is used to promote earthly kingship alone
questions.correctAnswer: The sword represents the word of God, piercing to judge and bring salvation
questions.explanation: The sword in Ezekiel 21 symbolizes God’s judgment, a theme echoed in Hebrews 4:12 where the word of God is described as a double-edged sword, and Revelation 1:16 where Christ’s mouth holds a sharp sword, linking judgment with salvation.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 21 reveal about the nature of sin and its consequences for nations?
options: Sin leads to divine judgment that can bring destruction on entire peoples
Sin is a private matter without national consequences
Nations are exempt from God's judgment if they have a few righteous individuals
God overlooks the sins of nations indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to divine judgment that can bring destruction on entire peoples
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 21 shows that sin results in God’s sword being drawn against entire nations, including Israel and the Ammonites (verses 3, 28-32), underscoring communal responsibility and divine justice as also seen in Nahum 1:2 and Jeremiah 25:15.
